title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.2 Arbitrariness: “ateş” (fire) in Different Scripts
It’s important to note that some of these are representations, as the scripts weren’t always used directly for modern Turkish, but for related languages or to approximate sounds.
Script | Representation |
Latin | ateş |
Arabic| آتش |
Cyrillic | атеш |
Runic | |
Mongolian | ᠢᠨᠪ |
Key Points:

No perfect one-to-one: It’s nearly impossible to find one Turkish word with a continuous, unbroken history in all these scripts.
Approximations: Older scripts, especially Runic, are about representing sounds, not designed for modern Turkish.
Related Languages: Chagatai is related, but distinct from Turkish. Mongolic script is for Mongolian, not Turkish.
Focus on the concept: This illustrates how similar word roots could be represented in different writing systems used across the Turkic and related language families.
